elements.name: Name dem Aufgaben
elements.title: Name the six rhetorical stylistic devices presented in the basic knowledge section.

elements.name: question1
elements.title: Life is a journey.
elements.correctAnswer: Metaphor: The sentence "Life is a journey" compares life to a journey. This is intended to convey the idea that life is full of experiences, just like a journey. It is a figurative paraphrase.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers.
elements.correctAnswer: Alliteration: In the sentence "Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers", all words begin with the letter P. This creates a memorable sound and makes the sentence easier to remember.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: What a beautiful day!
elements.correctAnswer: Irony: The sentence "What a beautiful day!" is said during a heavy downpour. In reality, it is not a beautiful day and the irony is used to express dissatisfaction with the weather.

elements.name: panel1
elements.title: Name the six rhetorical stylistic devices presented in the basic knowledge section.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: I'm so hungry, I could eat a whole horse!
elements.correctAnswer: Hyperbole: In the sentence "I'm so hungry, I could eat a whole horse!", hunger is greatly exaggerated. It is unlikely that someone could actually eat a whole horse. This exaggeration serves to emphasize how hungry a person is.

elements.name: question5
elements.title: Are you serious?
elements.correctAnswer: Rhetorical question: Suggestion: Anyone who asks the question "Are you serious?" is not expecting a real answer. It serves to express disbelief or astonishment at the behavior of another person.

elements.name: question6
elements.title: The sun laughs from the sky.
elements.correctAnswer: Personification: In the sentence "The sun laughs from the sky", the human ability to laugh is attributed to the sun. This describes a happy, sunny day.

elements.name: question7
elements.title: He has passed away.
elements.correctAnswer: Euphemism: In the sentence "He has passed away", death is described using a less direct expression. This serves to make the statement sound less harsh and to respect the grief of the bereaved.
